question: Does vitamin D status modify the relationship between calcium intake and serum parathyroid hormone levels in adults? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: After adjusting for relevant factors, serum PTH was lowest in the group with a serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level of more than 18 ng/mL but highest in the group with a serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level of less than 10 ng/mL.
content.source_2: In a population-based analysis of middle-aged adults, multivariable models showed no significant differences in serum PTH across strata of 25-hydroxyvitamin D; instead, calcium intake emerged as the sole independent predictor of PTH (P = 0.03), with no evidence of interaction between vitamin D status and calcium intake (P-interaction = 0.68). At calcium intakes above 1200 mg/d, PTH levels were indistinguishable between the lowest and highest vitamin D groups (P = 0.74).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS As long as vitamin D status is ensured, calcium intake levels of more than 800 mg/d may be unnecessary for maintaining calcium metabolism.
content.source_4: In a randomized, double-blind 12-month trial, raising serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D from below 10 ng/mL to above 18 ng/mL did not reduce PTH after adjustment for baseline calcium intake; PTH declines were similar among participants maintained on less than 800 mg/d versus more than 1200 mg/d calcium across all vitamin D strata (all P > 0.20). These results indicate that vitamin D status does not materially influence the calciumâ€“PTH relationship.
